byline.contributor: Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Alain Delaquérière, Peter Eavis and Nancy Sharkey contributed reporting.
byline.original: By DANIELLE IVORY, BEN PROTESS and KITTY BENNETT

abstract: Private equity firms have increasingly been taking over operation of 911 emergency services, applying combination of cost cuts, price increases, lobbying and litigation in effort to increase profits while reducing quality of service at same time; firms' expansion into basic civic services in aftermath of financial crisis points to their newfound pervasiveness, while lack of oversight has led to lengthening response times, equipment failure and citizen deaths (Series: Bottom Line Nation).
lead_paragraph: Since the 2008 financial crisis, private equity firms have increasingly taken over public services like emergency care and firefighting, often with dire effects.

headline.main: When You Dial 911 and Wall Street Answers
headline.print_headline: When You Dial 911  and Wall St. Answers

snippet: Since the 2008 financial crisis, private equity firms have increasingly taken over public services like emergency care and firefighting, often with dire effects.
